Message.Title: "AMD fires back at Intel's Haswell with its A-Series desktop processors"
Message.Msg: " On Saturday, Intel fired a salvo of ”Haswell” microprocessors across AMD’s bow. Now, Intel’s chief rival has responded in kind, with five new desktop processors that combine midrange microprocessor power with AMD’s powerful graphics technology. AMD’s A team is the A-series: the A10, A8, and A6 chips, aimed at Intel’s Core i3 and Core i5 microprocessors. Although AMD calls the chips its flagship offering, the A-series chips concede the high end of the market to Intel’s Core i7. On the other hand, they’re priced accordingly: AMD sells the low-end A6-6400K for $77, on up to the $149 A10-6800K. Overall, AMD says Richland will yield 21 percent more graphics performance (using the 3DMark “Fire Strike” benchmark) versus the previous generation, dubbed “Trinity,” as well as 8 percent more performance using the more generic PCMark 7 benchmark. That’s because the Richland chips include Radeon HD 8000-quality graphics. All of the Richland APUs are part of what AMD calls its “Elite A-Series” platform, and will be built into PCs from Acer and Hewlett-Packard."

Topic.Title: "AMD fires back at Intel's Haswell with its A-Series desktop processors"

Message.Msg: The article was from: PCWorld Take notes Nvidia fans this is a product launch. If you can read then you will see Prices, Specs, Benchmarks and OEMs selling products based on the NEW A-Series processors. You won't see any of that for Tegra 4 Today, will you? lmao imho

Message.Title: "AMD Touts Big Leap in Graphics Performance With New Richland APUs"
Message.Msg: "AMD Touts Big Leap in Graphics Performance With New Richland APUs" "Advanced Micro Devices on Wednesday launched a new desktop APU code named Richland which combines CPU and GPU performance in a single package that the chip maker said at the Computex show in Taiwan will hands-down beat rival Intel's offerings in the mainstream market. Richland is the next stage in AMD's A-Series APU lineup, which kicked off with Llano-class chips in 2011 and was followed up with Trinity last year. The chip maker said its Richland series boosts its 3DMark Fire Strike benchmarking score by 21 percent from the Trinity generation and has scored double-digit performance increases in other key benchmarking tests as compared with the preceding generation. AMD's Richland, utilizing the chip maker's Radeon 8000 series graphics, provides 779 GFLOPs of GPU compute performance to supplement a quad-core x86-based central processor capable of up to 4.4GHz clock speeds out of the box." Source: PCMag

Message.Title: "Why Qualcomm is likely to power Microsoft’s next Surface RT"
Message.Msg: "Why Qualcomm is likely to power Microsoft’s next Surface RT" ... "Qualcomm announced its support for Microsoft Windows 8.1 on Tuesday, which by itself is no big surprise. Here’s an interested bit from the press release, however: “At Computex Taipei 2013, Qualcomm Technologies is building on this innovation and collaboration with Microsoft by showing Qualcomm Snapdragon 800 processors running on an early version of Windows RT 8.1.” Again, this isn’t a huge surprise either but I haven’t seen any news of Nvidia showing off Windows RT 8.1. It could well be doing so — I’m not at the show — but there’s no press release to indicate any effort. For Nvidia, Computex seems to be an Android event. Sometimes words can be louder than actions Here’s another interesting angle: Which company has publicly supported Microsoft’s Windows RT effort? Both of course, but Nvidia has commented negatively about Windows RT sales. In March, Nvidia CEO Jen-Hsun Huang told developers that “Windows RT is disappointing to us because we expected to have sold more than we did.” While the sales disappointment is pretty obvious, some things are better left unsaid; especially when you’re a key Microsoft partner and supplying chips to the flagship device for the Windows RT platform." source: gigaom

Message.Title: Outlook gods speak: Outlook 2013 returning to Win RT
Message.Msg: This is NVIDIA's version: :) Earlier this year, our CEO Jen-Hsun Huang urged the Outlook gods to add Outlook to Windows RT. Apparently they listened. Microsoft announced at the Computex trade show in Taiwan that Outlook 2013 RT will be coming to Windows RT tablets later this year with the release of Windows 8.1. This is an exciting development that we believe will deliver a much more robust and full-featured experience to Windows RT users, including those with the Microsoft Surface RT, Lenovo Yoga 11, and ASUS VivoTab RT, which are all powered by NVIDIA Tegra 3. As Microsoft noted, consumers and business users alike have asked for Outlook for Windows RT, and we are thrilled that it will join the rest of the Office apps, Word, Excel, PowerPoint and OneNote, that are already available on Windows RT devices when the free update to Windows is available later this year in the Windows Store. We agree with Microsoft that the addition of Outlook on Windows RT, along with the announcements Microsoft made this week at TechEd on security, manageability and networking capabilities coming with Windows RT 8.1, makes Windows on ARM even more compelling for enterprises users. (from NVIDIA website)

Message.Title: Trefis: NVIDIA has huge potential in the mid-range smartphone market
Message.Msg: SOURCE: trefisDOTcom/stock/nvda/articles/190058/nvidia-has-huge-potential-in-the-mid-range-smartphone-market/2013-06-05 Quick Take Nvidia has decided to primarily focus on the mid-range smartphone market for now, competing directly with Qualcomm’s Snapdragon 400 chip. Qualcomm has been the leader in mobile chip market for many years while Nvidia is a relatively new player. Nvidia claims that its first fully integrated 4G LTE mobile processor – Tegra 4i – delivers almost three times higher performance than Qualcomm’s S400 solutions. LTE capability and competitive processor prices will increase Nvidia’s competitiveness in the smartphone market. With an estimated 487 million devices, the mid-range mobile market is projected to exceed the number of premium smartphones and tablets by 2015. The mobile device market and the LTE market are expanding at a rapid pace, and we believe that there is plenty of room for both Nvidia and Qualcomm to sell a higher number of processors in the future.

Topic.Title: Intel Haswell "hotter and slower than expected"

Message.Msg: Tom's Hardware has a good review of the i7-4770K. Users are going to want the graphics to run at 1080P or higher (MacBook retina is 1600) and this chip cannot play games higher than 720p. Even if the Iris Pro is 50% faster it is still not enough for anything over 1080P with decent levels of detail and you pay the huge ultrabook tax. So Intel is really only competing with itself as notebooks for gaming will still require dedicated gpu. And this fall DX11 and OpenGL 4.X become the standard for game engines so Intel graphics will lose more ground. Great CPU if you transcode video, gaming not so much.

Message.Title: Intel's ATOM is on a collision course with Core - and everybody loses
Message.Msg: SOURCE: PC World pcworldDOTcom/article/2040752/intels-atom-is-on-a-collision-course-with-core-and-everybody-loses.html Intel has made it clear that its fourth-generation Core or “Haswell” processors will power future PCs. But at the low end of the notebook market, the company's branding strategy will be far muddier—and that's bad for Intel, considering it needs to tell consumers exactly what to buy. On one hand, Intel needs to present a clear alternative to ARM, whose tablet partners dominate the mobile space and threaten traditional PCs. From a technical standpoint, Intel seems well on its way to solving that problem. Intel’s Haswell chip will eventually migrate to as little as 6 watts, Intel said Tuesday, meaning that its Core chips could eventually power tablets, too. But in the meantime, Intel's upcoming “Bay Trail” Atom chips are waiting in the wings—and could offer the performance buyers want at a fraction of the price. This fall, buyers looking to pick up an inexpensive Windows convertible or notebook may have to sort through several processor brands, including Atom, Core, Pentium, and Celeron. And that’s without even factoring in the code names: Bay Trail, Silvermont, and Haswell, among others. Intel may have the right chip at the right price, but because its processor line-up is so crowded, it's in real danger of screwing the whole thing up .......

Message.Title: BARRONS just in: Bernstein, JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley press downside thesis
Message.Msg: Part 1: "Intel (INTC) has enjoyed a relatively healthy rate of endorsements from the Street of late, with the unveiling two weeks ago of its “Silvermont” CPU for mobile devices, and the formal unveiling yesterday at the Computex conference of its “Haswell” processor architecture for everything from servers to low-power mobile devices. The announcement Monday morning by Samsung Electronics (005930KS) that the South Korean giant will use Intel’s “Clover Trail+” processor in its next “Galaxy Tab 10” tablet computer also heartened those with a bullish view of the stock, as it seems a major breakthrough in Intel’s attempts to crack a table market that’s been dominated by chips from competitors such as Nvidia (NVDA) and Qualcomm (QCOM). The latest victory was Monday’s upgrade to Outperform from Market Perform by FBR Capital‘s Christopher Rolland, who wrote that the company has “added enough new avenues of growth to replace lost PC units.” My colleague Jack Hough wrote an endorsement of Intel in this week’s Barron’s print magazine. However, it was the bears’ turn today to offer up what they see as the downside for the company and the stock. Stacy Rasgon of Bernstein Research reiterated an Underperform rating on the shares and an $18 price target, writing that “more than 100% of the stock’s performance year-to-date has been driven by multiple expansion (both from the market, and on a relative basis),” by which he means that the expansion of the stock market’s multiple, measured by the S&P 500, to 14.8 times at present, from 13 times forwarding earnings back in December, has been accompanied by an expansion of Intel’s relative stock multiple, from 0.83 the S&P multiple back in December to 0.91 at present. (To be continued)

Topic.Title: BARRONS just in: Bernstein, JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley press downside thesis

Message.Msg: Part 2: "But Rasgon thinks the stock is mainly benefiting from very low expectations: PC expectations have been extremely poor; the expectation now is that actual results will be merely bad, instead of truly abysmal. Secondly, Intel’s mobile product roadmap (as we have said for some time) appears very competitive; new BayTrail products for tablets appear compelling on power and performance vs. prior Atom generations [...] And thirdly, the company is in the beginning of a product cycle, with all attendant hype (exacerbated by Computex). Additionally they will be building product – fabs will be full, and gross margin outlook will (for now) climb upward as fab utilizations recover. Rasgon advises “not pressing the short here, but rather to use upside into the back half to short the stock,” and in addition to long-term structural challenges for Intel, such as the PC market not being a growth market, he sees some immediate reasons why the stock could face a tougher second half: Rolling out seasonality (given where numbers came in Q1) would suggest overall PC units down 5-10%. Intel, however, still believes computing units for them will grow, and is planning capacity build-out and loadings accordingly [...] 2014 unit expectations appear even more aggressive to us. Our analysis indicates that the company is implicitly suggesting fab output will increase in the high double digits YoY in 2014 [...] Additionally, given somewhat weak Data Center results in Q1, it is likely that the back half will need to be up more than 20% YoY in order to high company guidance for “double-digit” increases in the business. Currently the year appears to be setting up similarly to 2012, where Intel continued to build product on the hope of the Ivy Bridge refresh through the first three quarters, and was consequently forced to cut loadings and inventories at the end of the year. We model a repeat of last year’s events – namely an inventory flush and gross margin hit, starting in Q114.

Topic.Title: BARRONS just in: Bernstein, JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley press downside thesis

Message.Msg: Part 3 Morgan Stanley’s Joseph Moore, meanwhile, also reiterates an Underweight rating, and a $22 price target, writing that “Intel has already proven us wrong on Android,” where he had doubted the ability to Intel to win customers. However, “We are encouraged by these shifts, but still don’t like the stock.” Moore had written only two weeks ago that “We think Intel’s traction in the Android tablet market will remain fairly limited, given compatibility issues,” with developers on Android unwilling to move the most demanding applications to the Java or ”Dalvik” runtime environments. The Samsung win is “a key milestone” for Intel, he writes, and “the endorsement of Samsung could go a long way towards solving this chicken and egg problem” with developers. However, Moore thinks Intel “priced aggressively” to win the deal “both the CPU and the modem, which made the decision easier,” citing unnamed sources. He thinks the Samsung contract may boost Intel market share in tablets but may not help financial results much: Our prior assumption of 7.5% share of Android tablets will likely prove conservative given the Samsung announcement. But if Intel achieves 30% share of Android, it impacts our prior 2015 EPS estimate by just $0.04 as the opportunity is still relatively small compared to Intel’s total earnings stream. And lastly J.P. Morgan‘s Christopher Danely, who has a Neutral rating on Intel stock, and a $19 price target, writes that his visits in Asia this week with personal computer component suppliers suggest Q2 sales of PCs are trending below even reduced expectations. Danely thinks Haswell is not yet prompting “incremental demand” (though given the processor is new to market, it may be too soon to judge):

Topic.Title: BARRONS just in: Bernstein, JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley press downside thesis

Message.Msg: Part 4: Demand from the PC end market remains soft as Intel’s new Haswell processor is not driving incremental demand, touch-enabled PCs are still too expensive, and tablets and smartphones continue to cannibalize PC demand. Many companies we met with in the PC food chain stated 2Q13 is tracking towards the low end of guidance. We believe this is negative for Intel and Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) as both are over 85% exposed to the PC end market and guided 2Q13 and 2H13 to be in line with normal seasonal growth [...] Although Intel’s new Haswell microprocessor enables higher performance at lower power, none of the companies we met with indicated PC demand is improving. We do not expect Haswell to drive incremental PC demand as new processor launches have not historically resulted in higher PC demand. Like Moore, Danely is unimpressed with the financial prospects of Intel’s improved profile in tablet computers: Although Intel appears to be gaining tablet share at Samsung, Lenovo, and Acer, we believe the content and expected unit shipments are too small to offset declining demand in notebooks. We note the ASP of an Atom tablet processor is roughly $25-$30, well below Intel’s notebook microprocessor ASP of $110. Danely is modeling Intel revenue this quarter at $12.9 billion, the mid-point of Intel’s forecast, $12.9 billion, but for the full year he sees revenue of $53 billion, which is below the company’s forecast for revenue to rise in the “low single digits” on a percentage basis, and below Street consensus of $53.5 billion. blogsDOTbarronsDOTcom/techtraderdaily/2013/06/05/intel-bernstein-j-p-morgan-morgan-stanley-press-downside-thesis/

Message.Title: Rob Enderle says thisL "The doors of heaven open, angels are singing, Outlook is arriving on Windows RT""
Message.Msg: suliaDOTcom/channel/all-tech-science/f/de60cb2d-6de6-4f17-a870-db71e22092b1/?source=twitter ""Watching Microsoft repeat the mistake that IBM made with the PC Jr. back in the ‘80s with Windows RT has been painful. Crippling a product to assure a more expensive version has never ended well and leaving out both Outlook and Domain Join on Windows RT made it function like a crippled product. With this latest announcement Outlook will be added to Windows RT and while it still won’t get domain join, no other tablet will either, and there are a number of good work alternatives. I loved Windows RT’s battery life, price and weight but the lack of Outlook made it hard to use without screaming. With Outlook I’m having a religious moment. ""

Topic.Title: BARRONS just in: Bernstein, JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley press downside thesis

Message.Msg: Samsung doesn't have permanent bedfellows. They are looking for parts that are cheap, reasonably good performance, volume availability and, most importantly, requiring minimum development time. (ie. LTE bundled, or parts allowing turn-key like operations). Even with Samsung's immense marketing prowess, not all of its products are a HIT - case in point is Nexus 10 which, by the standard set with Nexus 7, is almost a FLOP. When Tegra 4i hits the ground, Sammie will come courting....and same with Logan next year for tablets, chromebooks or notebooks.

Message.Title: Shining a light on Intel silvermont claims
Message.Msg: ""ARM hit back at Intel this week at Computex, asserting that its Cortex CPU cores that ship today both outperform and run at lower power than Intel’s future next-gen mobile processor, Silvermont. Cores from the UK-based semiconductor IP group are known for their low-power capabilities and run a vast proportion of the world’s mobile devices. And they’re starting to get known for high performance, as well, such as with the quad Cortex-A15 CPUs built into Tegra 4, the world’s fastest mobile processor. But Intel has recently been claiming that Silvermont is 1.6 times faster and 2.4 times more power efficient than Cortex. ARM dismissed those charges at its event here in Taipei. It showed data with the accompanying chart that compares Cortex against Intel’s Silvermont claims. Based on actual measurements of Intel Atom chips shipping today and Intel’s own claims of future performance, today’s current performance of Cortex-A15 processors are 30% more efficient than Intel’s future Silvermont chip. ARM also noted that Intel’s x86 processors create compatibility issues on Android systems, which require them to “emulate” an ARM processor for apps to run properly. That’s no small issue, as fully 84% of the top games and 64% of top apps use native ARM code. Emulation, unfortunately, has several side effects. For starters, it doesn’t always work. And, when it does work, it degrades performance and burns more energy. That’s because the x86 processor is “emulating” the intended processor’s instruction set, which requires a lot of heavy lifting. In any event, neither option is helpful for a mobile device. There’s a rich tradition from the PC era of opposing architectures failing due to poor emulation results. SPARC, Transmeta and MIPS, among them. The moral of the story is there’s really no need to rely on emulation when so many great ARM-based solutions are already available. blogsDOTnvidiaDOTcom/2013/06/shining-a-light-on-intels-silvermont-mobile-processor-claims/
